list_definition.definition: (also adjective) (of) a substance put on walls, ceilings etc which dries to form a hard smooth surface

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: He mixed up some plaster to repair the wall

list_definition.definition: (also adjective) (also plaster of Paris) (of) a similar quick-drying substance used for supporting broken limbs, making models etc

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: She’s got her arm in plaster

list_definition.definition: (also sticking-plaster; Band-Aid American) (a piece of) sticky tape (sometimes with a dressing) used to cover a wound etc

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: You should put a plaster on that cut.

list_definition.definition: to spread or apply rather too thickly

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: She’d look nicer if she didn’t plaster so much make-up on her face.

list_ex_of_english: The rooms in these houses had thick plaster floors placed over a well-prepared base composed of small cobblestones.
The features consisted of two pits in the bedrock plastered with stucco to form subfloor basins.
